data.title: A Timeline of Finnish History
data.text:
98 Roman historian Tacitus wrote about the Fenni, a people of the north. This is the first reference to the Finns in recorded history.

ca 100 A.D. The ancestors of present-day Finns began to move into Finland.

1100s-1200s Sweden gradually conquered all of Finland.

1154 King Eric of Sweden introduced Christianity into Finland.

1238-1249 Birger, Earl of Sweden, led the Second Crusade to the Finnish inland province of Tavastia.

1290 Building work on Turku Cathedral began.

1293 Tyrgils Knutsson led Sweden's Third Crusade to Karelia.

1323 Sweden and Novgorod signed the Treaty of Pähkinäsaari, dividing up the territory of Finland.

1362 Finns were granted the right to send representatives to vote in Sweden's royal election.

1397 The kingdoms of Denmark, Sweden and Norway united into the Kalmar Union.

1475 Swedish nobleman Erik Axelsson Tott founded Olavinlinna castle in eastern Finland.

1493 Finland was mentioned for the first time on a printed map of Europe in the book Liber Chronicarum, authored by Hartmann Schedel in Germany.

1523 The Kalmar Union disbanded when Gustavus Vasa became King of Sweden.

~1540 The Swedish king made Lutheranism the official religion.

1543 Bishop Mikael Agricola produced the first Finnish-language book, a volume of Finnish grammar.

1548 The New Testament was translated into Finnish by Bishop Agricola.

1617 The Peace of Stolbova gave Sweden complete control of the entire Gulf of Finland.

1630-1643 Finnish cavalrymen distinguish themselves in the Thirty Years War.

1640 Queen Christina of Sweden established Åbo Akademi, the first university in Finland, in Turku.

1642 The entire Bible was translated into Finnish.

1700-1721 Russia won the Finnish province of Vyborg as a result of the Great Northern War.

1741-1743 Russia occupied all Finland.

1747 Construction of Sveaborg, a fortress on a group of islands off Helsinki, began.

1788-1790 Sweden and Russia fought over Finland.

1809 Finland became a grand duchy of the Russian Empire.

1812 Helsinki was declared capital of Finland.

1828 The university was moved to Helsinki.

1835 Elias Lönnrot published the Kalevala, a collection of traditional myths and legends that is now considered the Finnish national epic.

1848 The Finnish national anthem, Maamme, was performed in public for the first time.

1860 Finland acquired its own currency, the markka.

1863 Finland's own legislature, the Diet, convened for the first time.

1878 The Conscription Act gave Finland an army of its own.

1899 Czar Nicholas II made Russian the official language of Finland.

1902 Finnish became a fully equal official language.

1905 Finns staged a six-day nationwide strike which resulted in Russia restoring self-government within Finland.

1906 The Finns created their first Parliament elected by all adult citizens, including women.

December 6, 1917 Finland declared its independence from Russia.

1918 Finnish socialists and nonsocialists fought a civil war.

1919 Finland adopted a republican constitution and elected Kaarlo Juho Stählberg president.

1921 The League of Nations awarded the Aland Islands to Finland.

1926 Finland's first Social Democratic government took office. The Finnish Broadcasting Company, YLE, was established.

1930 The Communist Party was banned in Finland.

1932 Finland and the Soviet Union signed a non-aggression pact.

1939-1940 Russia defeated Finland in the Winter War.

1941-1944 Russia defeated Finland in the Continuation War.

1944-1945 Finland drove some 200,000 German soldiers out of Finnish Lapland and into Norway.

1944-1947 An Allied Control Commission was installed in Helsinki.

1946 President Juho K. Paasikivi established a policy of Finnish neutrality in international politics.

1948 Finland and the Soviet Union signed a Treaty of Friendship, Co-operation and Mutual Assistance.

1952 The Olympic Games were held in Helsinki.

1955 Finland joined the United Nations and the Nordic Council.

1956 Urho Kekkonen became president. He was re-elected in 1962 and 1968.

1961 Finland became an associate member of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA).

1973 The Finnish Parliament extended Kekkonen's term to 1978. Finland and other EFTA members entered free trade agreements with the European Community.

1989 Finland became a member of the Council of Europe.

1992 Finland and Russia concluded a treaty on good relations.

1995 Finland became a member of the European Union.

1999 Finland adopted European economic and monetary union.

2000 A new Constitution increased the parliamentary features of Finnish government.

2003 Anneli Jäätteenmäki, leader of the Center Party, became Finland's first female Prime Minister. She resigned amid scandal two months after taking office, however.

SEE ALSO

SwedenDenmarkNorwayRussiaHelsinki
